rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Analyzing War Era Propaganda
Project 1 | Concept Guide
rdf:Description.sioc:content:
Introduction:

Exploring Printed Media Types: This project explores propaganda and nationalism in World War era newspapers through an interactive process. By collecting multimedia content such as posters and newspaper articles, the project aims to create a dynamic platform that allows users to delve into propaganda techniques and their impact on public opinion. Through a narrative storyline spanning the war years, the project will highlight visual and written propaganda, showcasing their role in constructing national identity and support for the war effort.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Project 2 | Data Essay
rdf:Description.sioc:content:
Introduction:



Newspapers played a crucial role during the World War era, serving as one of the primary sources of information and shaping public opinion. Our project delves into these historical publications, examining how they influenced the rise of radical nationalism, particularly in countries like Germany. Through textual analysis, we aim to uncover the rhetorical devices and narrative techniques used by newspapers to promote extreme nationalist ideologies, often driven by propaganda. This broader examination provides a glimpse into the dynamics of wartime communication and the impact it had on society's understanding of the conflict.

Using an extensive archive from various countries involved in World War, our project explores how these publications changed in tone and content throughout the war. By analyzing linguistic features, rhetorical strategies, and thematic patterns, we seek to understand the mechanisms behind propaganda and how it influenced public perception. Our findings are presented through a series of interactive graphs and visualizations, allowing users to explore the data and gain insights into the socio-political climate of the era. Ultimately, this research aims to illuminate the power of the media in shaping social attitudes and contribute to the ongoing discussion on nationalism and propaganda.

Learn more about the topic by interacting with engaging data visualizations:

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: All Quiet on the Western Front
rdf:Description.sioc:content: All Quiet on the Western Front is a novel by Erich Maria Remarque, a German veteran of World War I.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: "The War of the Worlds" by H.G. Wells
rdf:Description.sioc:content:
"The War of the Worlds" by H.G. Wells (World War I era)
Paragraph showcasing its use for propaganda:
"The War of the Worlds" subtly fueled British patriotism during World War I by depicting a fictional Martian invasion of England. While the narrative primarily served as science fiction, its portrayal of humanity's resilience and ingenuity in the face of extraterrestrial threat was employed by British propagandists to boost morale and foster a sense of national unity. By drawing parallels between the fictional conflict and the real-life struggles of war, the book effectively contributed to the wartime propaganda effort, encouraging perseverance and solidarity among the British populace.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: "Mein Kampf" by Adolf Hitler
rdf:Description.sioc:content:
"Mein Kampf" by Adolf Hitler (World War II era)

Paragraph showcasing its use for propaganda:
"Mein Kampf" served as a cornerstone of Nazi propaganda during World War II, disseminating Hitler's extremist ideology and justifying his political ambitions. The book propagated racist theories, scapegoating Jews and promoting Aryan supremacy. Hitler strategically utilized its inflammatory rhetoric to rally support for his regime, depicting himself as a messianic figure destined to lead Germany to greatness. The widespread distribution of "Mein Kampf" played a significant role in indoctrinating the German population and garnering international sympathy for Nazi ideology, contributing to the spread of fascism across Europe.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: All Quiet on the Western Front by Erich Maria Remarque
rdf:Description.sioc:content: "All Quiet on the Western Front" starkly portrays the brutal realities of trench warfare, challenging the glorified narratives of heroism often perpetuated by wartime propaganda. Despite its anti-war sentiment, the book was co-opted by both Allied and Central Powers propagandists to illustrate the horrors of combat and justify their respective causes. By highlighting the physical and psychological toll of war on soldiers, Remarque's work subtly influenced public opinion and contributed to the broader discourse surrounding the conflict's human cost.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: "Radio Goes to War: The Cultural Politics of Propaganda during World War II" by Gerd Horten
rdf:Description.sioc:content:
"Radio Goes to War: The Cultural Politics of Propaganda during World War II" by Gerd Horten examines the significant role of radio broadcasting as a tool of propaganda during World War II. Horten delves into how radio programs were utilized by various nations involved in the conflict to disseminate information, shape public opinion, and mobilize support for their respective war efforts.

The book explores the cultural and political dynamics of wartime radio propaganda, analyzing the strategies and techniques employed by governments and broadcasters to influence listeners. Horten highlights the importance of radio as a mass communication medium during the war, reaching millions of people across borders and continents.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: British Propaganda in the Twentieth Century: Selling Democracy" by Philip M.
rdf:Description.sioc:content: "British Propaganda in the Twentieth Century: Selling Democracy" by Philip M. Taylor provides a comprehensive examination of the evolution of British propaganda from World War I to the Cold War era, with a particular emphasis on its role during World War II. Taylor delves into the strategies, methods, and messages employed by British propagandists to shape public opinion both at home and abroad.Throughout the book, Taylor analyzes various propaganda campaigns undertaken by the British government, exploring their objectives, target audiences, and effectiveness. He examines how propaganda was used to promote democratic values, bolster morale, counter enemy narratives, and build international support for the Allied cause during World War II.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: "Propaganda: The Art of Persuasion" by Anthony Rhodes
rdf:Description.sioc:content:
"Propaganda: The Art of Persuasion" by Anthony Rhodes explores the role of propaganda during World War II. Rhodes delves into how various nations, including the Allied and Axis powers, utilized propaganda techniques to influence public opinion, mobilize support for the war effort, and shape perceptions of the enemy.

The book examines the diverse forms of propaganda employed during the war, such as posters, films, radio broadcasts, and printed materials. It also analyzes the strategies and themes used in propaganda campaigns, from demonizing the enemy to promoting patriotism and sacrifice.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: British Propaganda in the Twentieth Century: Selling Democracy" by Philip M.
"British Propaganda in the Twentieth Century: Selling Democracy" by Philip M
rdf:Description.sioc:content: "British Propaganda in the Twentieth Century: Selling Democracy" by Philip M. Taylor provides a comprehensive examination of the evolution of British propaganda from World War I to the Cold War era

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: CHAMBERLAIN ANNOUNCES BRITAIN IS AT WAR WITH GERMANY
rdf:Description.sioc:content:
The newspaper article from the photo, "CHAMBERLAIN ANNOUNCES BRITAIN IS AT WAR WITH GERMANY," is a significant piece of historical journalism from September 3, 1939. The article reports on the declaration of war by Britain and France against Germany following the German invasion of Poland, marking the beginning of World War II.

The article is critical in several ways. First, it provides a detailed account of the events leading up to the declaration of war, including the final ultimatum given to Germany by Britain and France, and the subsequent failure of Germany to comply. The article also highlights the response of British Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain, who addressed the nation and announced the state of war between Britain and Germany.

Second, the article provides context for the declaration of war, including the German advances in Poland and the response of other nations, such as the Soviet Union and Italy. The article also notes the impact of the war on civilians, with reports of civilian casualties in Warsaw and the authorization of war credits by the French government.

Overall, the newspaper article is a critical source for understanding the beginning of World War II and the response of Britain and France to the German invasion of Poland.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Collier's Magazine
rdf:Description.sioc:content: The October 11, 1941, cover of Collier's Magazine is a powerful representation of American unity during World War 2. The illustration features a sailor, a soldier, and a marine standing together, symbolizing the collective effort and solidarity of the American military forces. This iconic image conveys a sense of strength, cooperation, and determination, highlighting the country's commitment to fighting against a common enemy. The unity depicted on the cover reflects the spirit of the American people during that time, as they came together to support the war effort and defend their nation's interests.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: country wise
rdf:Description.sioc:content:
WWII Propaganda Poster Project

 
Countries by Class Period: 
  • 2nd Period:  Germany
  • 3rd Period:  U.S.S.R.
  • 4th Period: U.S.S.R.
  • 5th Period:  Japan
  • 6th Period:  USA
  • ​7th Period: Britain
  
 
 
 
 
 

Examples of GERMAN propaganda.

Main German Viewpoints:
  • Members of the Axis Powers: their allies are Japan and Italy.
  • Believe that the Germans are a master race and that all other races/peoples are inferior.
    • Especially the Jews (Juden).  Jews are treated/viewed like animals or sub-humans.
  • Hitler is the supreme ruler and dictator.  He is considered the "father" of his nation.  Germans idolize him.
  • Nazi Swastika is their main symbol and is also represented on their flag. 
  • Germans want to gain "Lebensraum" or living space for the German people by taking over Europe and beginning what they call the start of the Third Reich (or basically Third German Empire).  
  • Dislike:  Britain, France, America, Russia, the Jews, the Gypsies, homosexuals, those with physical or mental disabilities, Africans and African Americans, basically anyone and everyone that is not a German white Aryan.
  • Hitler has shut down the majority of the churches and encouraged atheism or belief in the German state. 
  • Young children are sent away to Hitler Youth camps where they learn how to be good Nazi citizens, become members of the German army, and how to hate Jews and other undesirable races. 
 
 
 
 

Examples of BRITISH propaganda

Main British Viewpoints:
  • Members of the Allied Powers:  their allies are the French, Russia, America.
  • Had to face Germany alone after France fell and before Russia and the USA entered the war.
    • survived the Battle of Britain and the London Blitz
  • Leader is Winston Churchill. Many compare him to a bulldog which is also used as a symbol for the nation.  Considered fierce, loyal, and at times stubborn.
  • Fought (and defeated) Germany in WWI.
  • Encourages its citizens to help the war effort at home by saving resources, buying war bonds, supporting the troops, and having the women help in the workforce. 
  • Colors are navy blue, red, and white. Your flag is the union jack. 
  • You value freedom, individual rights, democracy, and the majority of you are either Catholic or Protestant (Christian). 
 
 
 
 

Examples of USSR propaganda

Main Russian Viewpoints
  • Member of the Allied Powers:  allies are France, Britain, and the USA.
  • Leader is Josef Stalin, dictator and absolute ruler of Russia. 
  • Russia (now know as the U.S.S.R.) is a communist nation.  They believe in the rights of the workers and peasants over the rich. All property and goods are product of the country and distributed by the government.
  • Enemies are: Germany, Italy, and Japan. But you also dislike your allies.  In fact you dislike anyone that isn't communist, so you pretty much just like yourself!
  • National symbols are the hammer and scythe (curved blade used to chop down wheat). These are the symbols of the industry workers and the farmers. 
  • Stalin is worshiped and idolized. Anyone who disagrees with him in Russia is killed. He is viewed as the father of the country. 
  • Colors are red and gold. 
  • Stalin has shut down the churches, and the communist state encourages people to be atheists and to believe in the state and communism as their religion. 
  • You want to stop Hitler and then spread communism to the rest of the world. 
 
 
 
 

Examples of JAPAN propaganda

Main Japanese viewpoints:
  • You are a member of the Axis Powers:  your allies are Germany and Italy.
  • You are ruled by Emperor Hirohito, whom the Japanese worship as a god.  You believe he is a supreme being and that you must do whatever he says. 
  • Honor is very important to you!  You believe that it is better to kill yourself than be captured, or be dishonored in any way through defeat. 
  • You want to expand your empire just like Britain and America have done.  You call yourself the Empire of the Rising Sun.
  • Your flag is red and white and has the outline of the sun on it. 
  • You value Japanese traditions, honor, family, the emperor, and your country. 
  • You dislike the Chinese, the Australians, the Americans, the British, and the Russians.  You think you should be able to establish your own colonies and empire just like other European nations have done so before. 
  • Your nation is highly militaristic and industrialized.  
  • A lot of your propaganda attacks "western" culture. You portray them as inferior, weak, dishonorable, and overly decadent. 
 
 
 
 

Examples of USA propaganda

Main USA viewpoints:
  • You are a member of the Allied Powers:  you allies are Britain, France, and Russia.
  • Your leader is President Franklin D. Roosevelt, better known as F.D.R.
    • He has been your president for 16 years (the longest anyone has ever been President of the United States). 
  • You value freedom, democracy, individual liberty, and the majority of you are Christian or believe in God in some form. 
  • Your women are entering the workforce to replace the men that went off to war. Children are collecting scrap metal and other resources to supply the war effort.  Everyone is encouraged to "do their part" for the war by buying war bonds, planting home gardens called victory gardens, and conserving resources. 
  • Your national mascot is Uncle Sam.  Your colors are red, white, and blue.  
  • Your enemies are the Japanese (who surprised attacked Pearl Harbor) and the Germans and Italians.  
  • You think your nation is pretty awesome and that anyone would be lucky to live there. You think once again, you are going to go into the war and save the day (just like you did with WWI).  You believe Americans can do anything they put their minds to.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Destroy This Mad Brute: Enlist
rdf:Description.sioc:content: Calling on American men to enlist, Harry Ryle Hopps's poster Destroy This Mad Brute: Enlist (1917) casts Germany as a barbarian who has arrived on U.S. shores, leaving behind a destroyed Europe

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Poster: Destroy This Mad Brute: Enlist (1917)
rdf:Description.sioc:content: Harry Ryle Hopps's poster Destroy This Mad Brute: Enlist (1917) depicts Germany as a barbarian that has come to the United States, leaving behind a ruined Europe, and calls for American men to enlist. The "mad brute" sports a mustache reminiscent of Kaiser Wilhelm II's whiskers and a spiked helmet with the word "militarism" engraved on it. He has seized a symbolic representation of Lady Liberty and is holding the bleeding German Kultur club tightly. Propaganda sent by the Allied troops frequently features the theme of the barbarian enemy, and the ape-like figure in particular—a forerunner to the film King Kong's title character from 1933—spoke to a public well-versed in Charles Darwin's theories of evolution.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Echoes of "Valor"
rdf:Description.sioc:content:
The Daily Mirror reproduces its 5 August 1914 front page, which - as befitted the million-selling title then marketed as Britain's "picture paper" - carried a series of almost relevant photographs to highlight the war's declaration.

On its back page were two more relevant pictures showing the flood of young men who signed up immediately to fight. The recruitment building, it said, "was besieged by would-be soldiers."
By leveraging powerful imagery to evoke a sense of national pride and solidarity. Through meticulously curated photographs, it illuminates the fervent patriotism that swept the nation, portraying the eager enlistment of young men as a testament to Britain's unwavering resolve in the face of conflict.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: NAZIS' STALINGRAD CHIEF CAPTURED, ONE OF LAST 2 POCKETS WIPED OUT; GERMANS ADVANCE IN MID- TUNISIA
rdf:Description.sioc:content:
The newspaper article from The New York Times, dated February 1, 1943, provides a comprehensive overview of significant events taking place during that time, both on the domestic and international fronts. The article is critical in understanding the context of World War II and the political climate in the United States.

On the international front, the article highlights the progress of the war, with the capture of the Nazi's Stalingrad chief and the wiping out of one of the last two pockets in Stalingrad. The article also reports on the advance of Germans in mid-Tunisia and the gratitude expressed by General Henri Honoré Giraud to the United States for their decisive help in the war. The article also mentions the loss of the Nazis' peril in Caucasus as the Russians take towns near Krasnodar.

On the domestic front, the article discusses the political developments, with Edward J. Flynn withdrawing his nomination as Minister to Australia and Ambassador to the South. The article also reports on the decrease in the taxable real estate and special franchises in New York City, indicating a decrease of $53,287,619 on the tentative assessment rolls for 1943-4. The article also highlights the meat quota plan proposed by Mayor La Guardia to stabilize and control the supply, distribution, and price of meat in New York and the nation.

Overall, the article provides a critical insight into the significant events taking place during that time, both on the domestic and international fronts. The article highlights the progress of the war, the political developments, and the economic situation, providing a comprehensive overview of the context of World War II and the political climate in the United States.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Get a war job!
rdf:Description.sioc:content: The poster is a vintage image from the World War era, featuring a woman with long hair and a red coat, holding a fan in her hand. The poster has a strong patriotic theme, with the words "Get a war job!" displayed prominently. The image was likely used as a recruitment tool to encourage people, particularly women, to join the workforce and contribute to the war effort. The message of the poster is clear: instead of longing for loved ones who are away at war, individuals can take action and support the war effort by getting a job. The poster's use of a female figure may have been intended to appeal to women and encourage them to take on new roles in the workforce, as many men were away fighting in the war. Overall, the poster likely had a significant impact on the mobilization of the civilian population during World War II.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: "Mein Kampf" by Adolf Hitler (World War II era)
"Loose Lips Sink Ships"
rdf:Description.sioc:content:
Visual propaganda wielded immense influence in shaping public opinion throughout World War II. Through the strategic use of symbolism and messaging, posters and cartoons became potent instruments for evoking emotions and galvanizing support for the war effort.

 A quintessential example of effective visual propaganda was the "Loose Lips Sink Ships" campaign, featuring a poster depicting a cartoon character with an exaggeratedly large mouth. This imagery served as a stark warning against careless talk that could jeopardize wartime operations. The campaign proved highly effective in instilling caution among the populace regarding the dissemination of sensitive information.Another iconic visual propaganda campaign was "Rosie the Riveter," epitomized by a determined woman declaring "We Can Do It!" in a poster. This campaign aimed to mobilize women into factory jobs, bolstering the war effort. Rosie the Riveter swiftly became a symbol of female empowerment, underscoring the indispensable role of women in wartime industries.

Visual propaganda wasn't confined to rallying support alone; it also served to promote specific policies and actions. Posters advocating for the purchase of war bonds or urging citizens to engage in war-related activities were pervasive. Through skillful use of symbols, messaging, and creative techniques, these campaigns effectively conveyed complex messages to the public, influencing their attitudes and behaviors.Moreover, visual propaganda played a crucial role in demonizing the enemy and fostering national unity. Depictions of adversaries as monstrous or savage beings were common, emphasizing the imperative of solidarity and collective resolve. Governments utilized visual propaganda to craft compelling narratives that unified populations and bolstered the war effort.

In essence, visual propaganda was a formidable force in shaping public sentiment during World War II. Through its adept manipulation of symbolism, messaging, and creative elements, posters and cartoons stirred emotions, rallied support, and steered millions toward a collective purpose. Its impact resonated deeply, shaping the trajectory of the war and molding the perceptions and actions of entire societies.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Introduction
rdf:Description.sioc:content:
The project seeks to delve into the intricate world of wartime propaganda, examining its techniques, messages, and impact on different societies. By analysing various media sources from multiple perspectives, we aim to understand how propaganda was a powerful tool of persuasion and manipulation during this tumultuous period. It Investigates the diverse range of propaganda techniques employed by different nations during World War, including emotional appeals, demonisation of enemies, patriotic fervour, and the manipulation of facts and statistics.

As the war has become more relevant than thought, this project wishes to explore the complexities of a conflict by scrutinizing various media sources used for propaganda, including newspapers, articles, books, pamphlets, and posters, and assess how each medium contributed to shaping public perceptions.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: "We Can Do It!" by J. Howard Miller's
rdf:Description.sioc:content:
During World War II, visual propaganda played a crucial role in shaping public opinion and supporting the war effort. Posters and cartoons were widely distributed and used to convey messages about the importance of the war, the need for sacrifice, and the potential consequences of defeat.

Symbolism in Wartime Posters:

During wartime, posters became powerful vehicles for conveying intricate messages and stirring deep emotions. Take, for instance, J. Howard Miller's iconic "We Can Do It!" poster, featuring the determined figure of Rosie the Riveter. Symbolizing the resilience and strength of American women, it encapsulated the vital role they played in the war effort.Symbolism, particularly the use of the color red, was a prevalent feature in many wartime posters. This hue evoked notions of danger, bravery, and sacrifice, while imagery depicting formidable animals like bears or eagles embodied the nation's resolve and fortitude.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Insights into the symbolism of wartime posters
Interactive Data Visualizations
rdf:Description.sioc:content: Below, you'll find interactive graphs that allow you to explore and analyze the data in detail. Use the available tools and controls to zoom in, filter, or change views to gain deeper insights into the data. Feel free to interact with the graphs to uncover trends, correlations, and other interesting patterns.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: It depicts the Kaiser’s war plans, highlighting areas Germany aimed to control.
Propaganda and Nationalism in World War Era Printed Media
The Blunt Reality of War in Vietnam
rdf:Description.sioc:content:
The cover story of the November 26, 1965, issue of LIFE magazine was titled "The Blunt Reality of War in Vietnam." The cover featured a striking photograph by Paul Schutzer, one of LIFE's most talented photographers. The photograph depicted a Vietcong prisoner with his eyes and mouth taped shut, providing a powerful and unsettling visual representation of the brutal conflict that was then raging in Vietnam.

Paul Schutzer was an accomplished photojournalist who had previously covered a wide range of subjects for LIFE, from the Civil Rights Movement in the United States to the space race between the US and the Soviet Union. His photograph of the Vietcong prisoner was just one of many that he took while on assignment in Vietnam, and it quickly became one of the most iconic images of the war.

Unfortunately, Schutzer's time as a photojournalist was cut tragically short. In 1967, while covering the Six-Day War between Israel and its Arab neighbors, Schutzer was killed when the armored personnel carrier he was riding in was hit by a Jordanian artillery shell. His death was a profound loss for the world of photojournalism, and his work continues to be celebrated and remembered to this day.

Overall, the cover of the November 26, 1965, issue of LIFE magazine provides a powerful and thought-provoking look at the realities of war, and the photograph by Paul Schutzer serves as a stark reminder of the human cost of conflict.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Rosie the Riveter
rdf:Description.sioc:content: Norman Rockwell's illustrations on the cover of Saturday Evening Post magazine were incredibly popular during World War 2. One of his most famous covers is indeed "Rosie the Riveter", which was published on May 29, 1943, not 1942. This iconic cover symbolized the role of women in the war effort, showcasing a female riveter with the name "Rosie" painted on her lunch pail. The image was a powerful representation of the significant contributions women made to the war effort, working in various industries such as aviation and munitions. Rockwell's "Rosie the Riveter" cover has become an enduring symbol of American women's participation in World War II.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Newspaper Article
rdf:Description.art:url: https://scalar.usc.edu/works/dgt212-group8/media/Tangled Webs History_ Headlines from the Past.jpeg

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: "Second Happy Time"
rdf:Description.sioc:content:
This campaign involved German submarines targeting Allied merchant shipping along the U.S. coast, taking advantage of the initially weak U.S. antisubmarine defences.

By publicising U-boat attacks, the government could emphasise the severity of the threat posed by the Axis powers and highlight the need for a united national effort to counter this threat. It highlighted the aggressive actions of Germany and its allies, portraying them as ruthless adversaries who posed a direct threat to the safety and security of the United States. This narrative could reinforce the idea that the U.S. was justified in its involvement in the war and needed to continue fighting until victory was achieved. This could help maintain morale on the home front and bolster support for the war effort during challenging times.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: "The Stars and Stripes Flying in the Ancient Coliseum at Rome"
rdf:Description.dcterms:description: On the Occasion of Italy's Rejoicing Over the Entry of the United States into the War."
rdf:Description.sioc:content: Patriotic propaganda and a succession of censorship laws, beginning with the Espionage Act of June 15, 1917, went into full swing. Photographs in the rotogravure sections showed scores of young men registering for the draft—the American flag visible in more than half the images. Pictures of German soldiers ceased, as did any stories from German or Austro-Hungarian perspectives. Countless portraits of a heroic President Wilson appeared. In June, the war drive became a competition to see which state or city was the most patriotic—the New York Times posted daily graphics showing which states contributed the most recruits and purchased the most war bonds. As intervention became imminent, newspapers ran fewer photographs from the battlefield and replaced them with pictures of parades and training regiments. Editorial policies became even more vigorously pro-American once American soldiers began to fight in the war.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: "Sun's WWI Centenary Supplement: A Blend of History, Humor, and Remembrance"
rdf:Description.sioc:content:
The Sun tells the story of the war through a 12-page supplement, which tells the story through a series of trademark Sun-style front pages, with headlines such as "Fritz in bitz" and "Kaput".

The best part of them is reworking the Dad's Army theme song, which refers to Mr Hitler. This one says: "Who do you think you are kidding, Mr Kaiser?" Also note the self-deprecating byline, "Meg Lomania."

Its main front page is also devoted to the centenary. It backs the initiative by Prime Minister David Cameron to call on its readers to "light a candle at 10 pm tonight". And there are two pages inside asking everyone to remember the fallen of the great war.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: "Propaganda: The Art of Persuasion" by Anthony Rhodes
Radio Goes to War – The Cultural Politics of Propaganda During World War II
Remember Always - Nothing German
rdf:Description.sioc:content: A British World War I propaganda stamp promoting the purchase of British goods and the avoidance of German goods. The stamp shows Britannia pointing to what is probably the sinking of the Lusitania in 1915. It was printed by Perkins Bacon. It was part of a broader propaganda campaign aimed at bolstering patriotism and supporting the war effort.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Mein Kampf
rdf:Description.sioc:content: Mein Kampf is a 1925 autobiographical manifesto by Nazi Party leader Adolf Hitler.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Punch and Judy
rdf:Description.sioc:content:
During World War II, political cartoons emerged as potent tools for shaping public sentiment and galvanizing support for the war endeavor. Far from being mere advertisements, these cartoons were meticulously crafted works of propaganda, employing humor, satire, and symbolism to convey nuanced emotions and ideas.

Among the notable cartoonists of the era, David Low stood out with his renowned "Punch and Judy" series. Featuring a British and a German soldier portrayed as children engaged in a war game, Low's choice of characters was deliberate, aiming to highlight the absurdity of conflict and advocate for peace. Through his use of wit and satire, Low delivered a poignant commentary on the futility of war and the imperative of global harmony.Similarly impactful was George Orwell, whose allegorical novel "Animal Farm" employed animals as proxies for various political factions. Serving as a cautionary tale against totalitarianism, Orwell's work underscored the significance of individual liberty and democratic principles. By employing animal symbols, Orwell adeptly conveyed profound messages about the importance of freedom and democracy.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Nazi Congress in Nuremberg, Germany (1936) | British Pathé
rdf:Description.dcterms:description: Crowds of people gather at a Nazi rally in Nuremberg, Germany in 1936 to watch Adolf Hitler speak 3 years prior to World War II.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Others
rdf:Description.sioc:content:
The War of the Worlds

 
 
Mein Kampf
All Quiet on the Western Front
 
Selling Democracy

 
 
Propaganda: The Art of Persuasion
Radio Goes to War

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: "WAKE UP, AMERICA! CIVILIZATION CALLS EVERY MAN WOMAN AND CHILD!"
rdf:Description.sioc:content:
The poster is a vintage piece of propaganda from the World War era, featuring a woman dressed in patriotic attire symbolizing the United States. The woman is depicted lying down with her eyes closed, giving the impression that she is either sleeping or resting. The text on the poster reads "WAKE UP, AMERICA! CIVILIZATION CALLS EVERY MAN WOMAN AND CHILD! MAYOR'S COMMITTEE 50 EAST 42* ST."

The poster's primary goal is to rally and mobilize the American people, particularly those in the city, to take action and contribute to the war effort. The use of a female figure dressed in patriotic colors is a common trope in propaganda from this era, intended to evoke a sense of national pride and unity. The phrase "WAKE UP, AMERICA!" is a call to action, urging citizens to recognize the urgency of the situation and to get involved.

During the World War era, posters like this one were a common sight in public spaces, and they played a significant role in shaping public opinion and mobilizing support for the war effort. The impact of this poster would have been to inspire a sense of duty and responsibility in the American people, encouraging them to do their part to support the war effort and defend their country. The use of emotional language and imagery was a powerful tool for rallying support and building a sense of national unity during a time of crisis.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: UNITED WE WIN
rdf:Description.sioc:content:
The poster is a black and white image of two men working on an aircraft engine. The men are dressed in work clothes and are shown collaborating on the engine, which has a large propeller. The phrase "UNITED WE WIN" is written twice on the poster, once at the top and once at the bottom.

During World War II, this poster was likely used as propaganda to promote unity and cooperation among workers in the war effort. The image of the two men working together on the aircraft engine emphasizes the importance of collaboration and teamwork in achieving a common goal. The phrase "UNITED WE WIN" reinforces this message, suggesting that victory can only be achieved through unity and collective action.

The black and white color scheme of the poster may have been chosen to convey a sense of seriousness and urgency, as well as to reflect the stark realities of war. The use of bold, capital letters for the phrase "UNITED WE WIN" further emphasizes the importance of this message and helps it stand out on the poster.

Overall, this poster would have likely had a significant impact on those who saw it during World War II, inspiring them to work together and contribute to the war effort in any way they could.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: "Propaganda: The Art of Persuasion" by Anthony Rhodes
rdf:Description.sioc:content: "Propaganda: The Art of Persuasion" by Anthony Rhodes explores the role of propaganda during World War II.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Radio Goes to War – The Cultural Politics of Propaganda During World War II
rdf:Description.sioc:content: Radio Goes to War: The Cultural Politics of Propaganda during World War II" by Gerd Horten examines the significant role of radio broadcasting as a tool of propaganda during World War II.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Term Frequency Chart
rdf:Description.sioc:content:
The Term Frequency chart of abstracts of 11 papers related to the project concept notes titled “Propaganda and Nationalism in World War Era Newspapers” provides insights into the relative frequencies of words used in the context of digital humanities exploration of propaganda and
nationalism. The chart highlights the prominence of certain terms, including “War”, “Public”, “Propaganda,” “Nazi” and “Media.”

It is not unexpected that the word "war" has the highest relative frequency of 0.0025 given the project's concentration on the World War era. This periodicity implies that the project will look at how the media and propaganda shape national sentiment and public opinion during times of war.
The project will investigate how media and propaganda target and influence the general public, as evidenced by the word "public"' moderate relative frequency of 0.006. This is a crucial part of the project since, in times of conflict, the media and propaganda have a big influence on the
opinions and actions of the general people.

The concept of "propaganda" is crucial to the project and has a relative frequency of 0.0045. The project's goal is to investigate how propaganda shaped nationalism and public opinion throughout the World War era. The project aims to expose political persuasion tactics and
comprehend how they affected the public by examining propaganda materials.

The relative frequency of the word "nazi" is 0.0035, indicating that the project will look at how Nazi propaganda and the media shaped nationalism and public sentiment throughout World War II. This is an essential part since Nazi propaganda and the media were vital in advancing National Socialism as an ideology and defending the regime's policies.

The relative frequency of the word "media" is 0.003, indicating that the project will look at how various media outlets spread lies and influence public opinion. This is a vital part because the public's perception and reception of propaganda can be greatly influenced by the media.
The words "War," "Public," "Propaganda," "Nazi," and "Media" are crucial to comprehending the studies on nationalism and propaganda during the World War Era, the abstract map concludes.We can determine the main topics and regions of concentration in the project idea notes by comparing the frequency distributions of these phrases, which offers important insights into the interplay among nationalism, media, and propaganda in the years leading up to World War II.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Terms Berry
rdf:Description.sioc:content:
A Terms Berry is a visualization that shows the frequency of words across a series of documents or texts. It presents a timeline of how frequently certain terms appear in the corpus. Here's how you might interpret it:

  • Temporal Trends: The Terms Berry would reveal temporal patterns in the occurrence of key terms throughout the corpus of abstracts. For example, you might observe spikes in the frequency of terms like "propaganda" and "media" during specific periods of wartime activity, indicating increased attention to these topics during times of heightened conflict.
  • Comparative Analysis: By comparing the frequency of terms across different documents or groups of documents, you can identify shifts or consistencies in thematic emphasis over time or across different contexts.
  • Key Moments: Peaks in the frequency of certain terms may coincide with significant historical events or developments related to propaganda and nationalism during the World War era. These moments could serve as focal points for further analysis and exploration within your project.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Word Cloud
rdf:Description.sioc:content:
A word cloud visually represents the frequency of words in a text, with more frequent words appearing larger and more prominent. In the context of your project concept notes, a word cloud generated from the abstracts of the 11 papers related to "Propaganda and Nationalism in World War Era Newspapers" would likely emphasize key terms that are central to the theme of your research. Here's a potential interpretation:

  • "War": Given the focus on the World War era, the word "war" would likely appear prominently in the word cloud, indicating its significance as a central theme.
  • "Propaganda": As one of the main topics of investigation, "propaganda" would also feature prominently, highlighting its importance in shaping national sentiment and public opinion during wartime.
  • "Nazi": Given the specific focus on World War II and its propaganda, "Nazi" would likely stand out as a significant term, indicating the attention given to examining Nazi propaganda's role in shaping public sentiment.
  • "Media": Another key term, "media" would likely be sizable in the word cloud, illustrating its importance in disseminating propaganda and influencing public opinion during wartime.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The map serves as a vivid example of wartime nationalism and geopolitical aspirations.
The War of the Worlds by HG lewis
rdf:Description.dcterms:description: It was written between 1895 and 1897, and serialised in Pearson's Magazine in the UK and Cosmopolitan magazine in the US in 1897.
rdf:Description.sioc:content: The War of the Worlds is a science fiction novel by English author H. G. Wells.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: This World War One propaganda map advocates for American intervention.

War! OAHU BOMBED BY JAPANESE PLANES
rdf:Description.sioc:content: Japanese Planes bombed OAHU leading to great loss.
